inlineContent.text: In KeyboardKit, the
enum defines a set of keyboard-specific actions that can be bound to buttons and handled with a
KeyboardKit will by default create a
and apply it to the input controller‚Äôs
. You can replace it with a custom handler to customize how actions are handled.
The
enum can be grouped into categories. The descriptions below are the standard behaviors when actions are handled with a
- inserts a text character when released.
- inserts a text character when released, rendered as empty space.
- inserts an emoji when released.
- inserts a space when released and moves the cursor when long pressed.
- inserts a tab when released.
- deletes backwards when pressed, and repeats that action until it‚Äôs released.
- dismisses the keyboard when released.
- can be used to show a specific emoji category.
- changes the keyboard type when pressed.
- moves the input cursor back one step when released.
- moves the input cursor forward one step when released.
- triggers the keyboard switcher action when tapped and long pressed.
- triggers the locale switcher action when long pressed and released.
- changes the alphabetic keyboard casing when released and double tapped.
- represents a command (‚åò) key.
- represents a control (‚åÉ) key.
- represents a dictation key.
- represents an escape (esc) key.
- represents a function (fn) key.
- represents an option (‚å•) key.
- represents a primary button, e.g.
etc.
- a custom action that you can handle in any way you want.
- can be used to refer to an image asset.
- a ‚Äúno action‚Äù placeholder action.
- a custom action that can be used to e.g. show a settings screen.
- can be used to refer to a system image (SF Symbol).
Keyboard actions can be handled with a
, which is a protocol that can be implemented by any class that can be used to handle keyboard actions.
You can trigger actions programmatically by calling
with a
and a
Keyboard actions can also be triggered by keyboard-specific gestures that are applied to buttons. If you use a
, action gestures will be automatically applied to the various buttons.

content.text: How to create a custom action handler

inlineContent.text: You can create a custom
to customize how keyboard actions are handled, or to handle actions that have no default behavior.
You can create a custom action handler by inheriting the
base class, which gives you a lot of functionality for free, or by implementing
from scratch.
For instance, here is a custom action handler that inherits
and extends it with the capabilities to copy and save images:

code: let standard = super.action(for: gesture, on: action)
case .image(_, _, let imageName): return { [weak self] _ in self?.saveImage(named: imageName) }
case .image(_, _, let imageName): return { [weak self] _ in self?.copyImage(named: imageName) }

inlineContent.text: To use this action handler instead of the standard one, just set the input controller‚Äôs
to the new handler:
This will make KeyboardKit use your custom implementation instead of the standard one.
